question: My father, though he is only in his early fifties, is stuck in his old-fashioned <u>ways. He has a</u> general mistrust of any innovation or technology that he can’t immediately grasp and he always tells us, that if something isn’t broken, then you shouldn’t fix it.

My father, though he is only in his early fifties, is stuck in his old-fashioned ways. He has a general mistrust of any innovation or technology that he can’t immediately grasp and he always <u>tells us, that</u> if something isn’t broken, then you shouldn’t fix it.
He ran a small grocery store in town, and if you were to look at a snapshot of his back office taken when he opened the store in 1975, you would <u>see that not much has changed since.</u>
a: not be likely to see very much that has changed since.
b: be able to see right away that not very much has changed since.

question: My father’s state-of-the-art computer now serves as a very expensive bulletin board for the hundreds of adhesive notes he uses to keep himself organized. <u>Sooner than later,</u> we fully expect it will completely disappear under the mounting files and papers in the back office.
Read the passage from Hamlet, by Shakespeare. Which of the following BEST describes the conflict in this soliloquy by Hamlet?
a: An internal conflict about whether it is better to live or to die.
b: An internal conflict about whether to kill his stepfather or not.
c: An external conflict with his friends and family who are opposed to his taking up arms to fight the enemy.
d: An external conflict with his priest about whether it is moral to take another person's life or not.

question: Read the passage from Hamlet, by Shakespeare. What character traits for Hamlet are revealed through the author's wording?
Read the passage from Hamlet, by Shakespeare. Which of the following is NOT a function of this internal speech from Hamlet?
a: To describe an external conflict between Hamlet and the nature of the world.
b: To spark empathy in the reader for Hamlet's situation.
c: To demonstrate the broader thematic elements of the play.
d: To create loathing for Hamlet in the reader.

question: Read the passage from Hamlet, by Shakespeare. In the context of the soliloquy, the phrase 'the rub' most likely means which of the following to Hamlet?
a: The problem with not knowing what happens after death.
b: The physical pain that Hamlet has endured.
d: The act of suicide that Hamlet is considering.

question: Read the passage from Hamlet, by Shakespeare. Starting with the line 'For who would bear...', what rhetorical device is used in the last few lines of the passage?
Throughout human history, mankind <u>sought</u> to track the days and seasons.
<u>Tracing back millennia, archaeologists have discovered calendars,</u> showing the ancient views of the earth’s movement and time’s passage.
a: Tracing back millennia, calendars were discovered,
b: Calendars tracing back millennia have been discovered by archaeologists
c: Archaeologists have discovered calendars tracing back millennia,

question: Several cultures created lunisolar calendars, using <u>both solar and lunar measurements</u> to determine the year and month.
The Roman calendar was often <u>stabilized</u> by political goals: years were lengthened or shortened to adjust terms of office.

<u>Even if</u> technological advances in communication are often considered from a social standpoint, as people can connect more and more easily, one sector that has been immensely affected is the career sector.
Online meetings can <u>hold</u> from the comfort of an office.
Technilogical glitches can make virtual meetings <u>boring</u>.
Consider the short excerpt. Which one of the following most accurately states the main point of the passage?
a: The overly conservative rulings of Canada’s provincial courts have been a barrier to constitutional reforms intended to protect aboriginal rights.
b: The overwhelming burden placed on provincial courts of interpreting constitutional language in Canada has halted efforts by aboriginal peoples to gain full ownership of land.
c: Constitutional language aimed at protecting aboriginal rights in Canada has so far left the protection of these rights uncertain due to the difficult task of interpreting this language.
d: Constitutional reforms meant to protect aboriginal rights in Canada have in fact been used by some provincial courts to limit these rights.

question: Consider the short excerpt. The passage provides evidence to suggest that the author would be most likely to assent to which one of the following proposals?
a: Aboriginal peoples in Canada should not be answerable to the federal laws of Canada.
b: Provincial courts should be given no authority to decide cases involving questions of aboriginal rights.
c: The language of the Canadian constitution should more carefully delineate the instances to which reforms apply.

The author’s feelings toward Louis Brandeis can by characterized each of the following EXCEPT:
